moves.1. e4 c5: The Sicilian.  I play it myself but don't necessarily do very well against it ...
moves.2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3: The Dragon Variation, not something I know much about, though I am doing alright in a tourney devoted to it on Gameknot at present.
moves.6. Bc4 Bg7 7. Be3 Nc6: Both sides are developing as quickly as possible at this stage.  There are, of course, many options at each move but I think this is a main line.
moves.8. f3: Supports e4 and prevents the annoying ..Ng4
moves.8... O-O 9. Qd2 Bd7 10. Nde2: White keeps his options open as to which side to castle for as long as possible.
moves.10... a6: Is this to prevent White's N or B from moving to b5 or to support ...b5?  Or both?
moves.11. Bh6: Fulfilling the purpose of 9. Qd2 but is the timing right?  White doesn't seem to have a convincing follow-up and is still slightly vulnerable due to being uncastled.
moves.11... Ne5: Black counters with an attack on the undefended Bc4.
moves.12. Bb3: So the B retreats to its predetermined refuge.
moves.12... Rc8: A standard developing move occupying the half-open c-file, typical of the Sicilian.
moves.13. h4: With the g7-h6 situation unresolved, White sees an opportunity to increase the pressure with a kingside storm.  This rather commits White to either castling queenside or not castling at all, which both seem high-risk options, given the way that Black's pieces are arranged.
moves.13... Nc4: The N forks White's Q and bP.  The threat on the Q undermines her support of the B on h6.  I his uncastled position, White needs to be v careful.
moves.14. Bxc4: So White swaps the long-term asset, the WSB, for the immediately threatening N.
moves.14... Rxc4 15. O-O-O: ... and finally commits to the Q-side.  I think White's K-side attack is slightly more advanced than Black's Q-side attack.  Let's see...
moves.16. Kb1: A standard defensive move when castled Q-side - but isn't it a bit slow?  I always find these decisions very difficult but I think the Ns were too tied down while the a-pawn was not defended by another piece.
moves.16... Rfc8: Black proceeds to increase the pressure on the recently castled K.  White's decision doesn't look too wise at present.  Since the castling, Black has made 2 seriously attacking moves, White is on the defensive.
moves.17. Bxg7: Time to resume the offensive before it's too late ...
moves.17... Kxg7 18. g4 b5: Classic attack and counter-attack on opposite wings.
moves.19. h5 b4 20. hxg6: White allows bxc3 in order to deliver Qh6+, intending to deliver mate before Black can.
moves.20... fxg6 21. Qh6+ Kg8 22. g5: To dislodge the N that protects h7
moves.22... Nh5 23. Rxh5: Now White commits fully to the attack by sacrificing the exchange.  It's win or bust!
moves.23... gxh5 24. Nd5: Another critical decision.  The N moves from defence, where it was attacked, to attack, threatening a fork on e7.  Black has no immediately obvious attacking responses so ...
moves.24... Qd8: Black protects e7 but his attack loses its sting.
moves.25. g6: Threatens immediate mate or crushing opening of lines and a future mate.
moves.25... hxg6 26. Qxg6+ Kf8 27. Rg1: Black resigned as mate could not be prevented.
